thread.title: Jose Mourinho shouldn't have to gee up United fans for Liverpool clash - an Anfield crowd would ALWAYS be up for it
thread.title_full: Jose Mourinho shouldn't have to gee up United fans for Liverpool clash - an Anfield crowd would ALWAYS be up for it

author: irishmirror
title: Jose Mourinho shouldn't have to gee up United fans for Liverpool clash - an Anfield crowd would ALWAYS be up for it
text:
Jose Mourinho wants more from Manchester United fans Share this video Watch Next The Echo's Chris Beesley argues an Anfield crowd would ALWAYS be up for this game (Photo: Laurence Griffiths) 
Mourinho’s players are used to being given a rocket by their demanding coach but this must have been a chastening experience for the fans. 
You’d expect any ground to be bouncing for a semi-final, or have United’s supporters become so blasé, so spoiled by success that they don’t bother any more? 
It’s not our concern but it’s to be hoped not. 
Also, given that it’s hardly been a bed of roses since Sir Alex Ferguson’s departure, with Mourinho becoming their third manager in three years after the Scot’s retirement, those big prizes (like the football) that were once taken for granted have no longer been as free-flowing. Klopp takes his side to Old Trafford on Sunday (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
It’s over 16 years now since former United captain Roy Keane delivered his infamous “Prawn sandwich” tirade towards the corporate clients within their stadium, but Mourinho feeling compelled to gee up Old Trafford’s rank and file supporters ahead of such a powderkeg fixture against their greatest rivals represents a whole different ball game. 
With increased demands of dealing with agents, sponsors and media, the remit of high-profile Premier League managers is continuing to expand. yet having to resort to such remarks in a post-match briefing for the Hull game had an air of desperation about it. 
What next, Jose donning full Toni Braxton cheerleader costume and whipping the Stretford End into a frenzy with his pom poms? 
As someone who has felt the full force of the Anfield crowd when it comes to big games, Mourinho knows how crucial a partisan and vociferous home support can be on such occasions. 
And that’s where a crucial difference between Liverpool and United seems to lie. View gallery 
No top-flight English side seems to be immune from the problem of sterile atmospheres for run of the mill matches. Anfield is no different in this respect. 
In his time at the club so far, Reds boss Jurgen Klopp has already gone on record on more than one occasion when it comes to trying to cajole certain elements of the stadium into being more proactive. 
But you can guarantee whenever Liverpool’s players need them, and certainly each time Manchester United are in town, the Kop and company are guaranteed to deliver. 
The task this weekend from Klopp’s troops will be to ensure the Old Trafford patrons remain silent. 
If they accomplish that for 90 minutes, you might just be able to hear the cheers from back on Merseyside. poll loading Who will win Sunday's clash at Old Trafford? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
